transformed_texts: I think the Catholic Church needs to change in some ways. They have strong views which are fine but a bit outdated. They have been talking about how the Catholic Church is losing some of its followers and I think it's because the Catholic Church isn't very accepting of a lot of things. For example, gay marriages, abortion, birth control, etc. They have a very strong viewpoint on these things which is understandable. But the problem is if they were to adapt to a bit of a newer way of thinking they wouldn't be worried about losing followers. Some people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because they see their stance on these issues as old-fashioned and so some people are starting to disagree with them on certain subjects. They feel that the Catholic Church has the wrong view on things. The Catholic Church is against abortion, so if you're for abortion you might not be comfortable following a church that teaches it's completely wrong and that you're against it. The same goes for gay marriage, etc. If you believe in it and want to do it or feel strongly about it, you might not want to be in a church that doesn't agree with that. I don't see any reason why women can't be priests or why priests can't be married. But I don't know if that would have prevented what happened. I don't know if they would have done things differently if they were allowed to be married or have women priests. But I don't know if that would have changed things. They did what they did and that didn't seem to be affected. I mean, if they were married would they have done things differently? It's hard to really tell. I don't see why priests can't be married, the Catholic Church says that priests are married to God and devote their whole life to God, but everyone else who has a job in the world has their job and also has their family life and other people they're devoted to, so I don't see why priests can't have both.

I personally don't oppose same-sex marriage. I think people's sexual orientation isn't a conscious choice. So I think gay people shouldn't be blamed for their sexual orientation. I think it's unfair. Because they don't choose their sexual orientation. I think sexual orientation isn't an option. People can't choose whether they're gay or straight. I'm straight, another person is gay, that's how they're born. I think it's not a conscious choice. So I think they shouldn't be blamed. I think the government shouldn't interfere with this issue because it's not a legal issue. It's not a moral issue either. I don't think it's a national security issue. The government shouldn't interfere with personal matters. Everyone should have the right to choose their own life. Gay people should be treated with dignity and respect.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there's not really a good reason not to. Many people think that gay couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's completely different. Gay marriage has many aspects, and it can't be compared to heterosexual marriage. It's like two sides of the same coin - it will never be the other side. However, it's still the same thing. Gay couples have a lot of civil rights that come with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing, where their partner can't be in the room with them if they're sick, and can't visit because they're not technically family. And I think that's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have been done because it's a hot topic these days, and gay couples have the same kind of success rates as heterosexual couples. They have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It's just a relationship, it's the same thing. And I think where a lot of people get hung up on is that gay people aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state, then that shouldn't be an issue. Because I don't understand how people, like Catholics, can get hung up on, "Oh, that's against our religion, and that's morally wrong for us, and we can't approve of that kind of thing." But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. Yeah, they are, they're the same in many ways, like the type of relationship roles played by different partners, and stuff like that. And people worry about adoption issues, and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. And especially about, um, children of gay couples, and how they'll adjust to society, and whether or not they'll be influenced by their parent's sexual orientation choices or not. But well, again, it's kind of new, and stuff, but it's kind of hard to say I'm not sure about the children aspect about adoption, because I think the main drawback to that is, um, how children get treated by their peers, and by other adults in society. Like in New York City, I know they have special schools for children of gay parents, because in public schools in New York City, they get like beaten up. And stuff like that, parents protest to get the child removed from their school, and it's just a kid, I mean, they're gonna have the same points of view, and everything, parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight couples. And so, they can be community involved or not, like heterosexual couples choose to, I mean it's just about personality choices. I think the federal government should be very involved in this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state, I think the amendment should just be the opposite. But well, I think President Bush has very very strong views of his own having to do with his religion. His take on gay marriage actually, um, I think it goes along with his take on abortion, and stem cell research which, um, I think most of the reasons, I'm not sure about this, because honestly I try not to pay attention to politics a lot, but most of the reasons I've heard at least like in the news and stuff are moral reasons, and morality I don't want to say it's negotiable, but it definitely differs from person to person, and to embrace the morality of a certain group in America while totally ignoring the culture and morality concepts of all the rest is unethical, to just go along with what some religious groups believe without taking into account the morality of others is completely hypocritical of the government considering the recent controversy, considering I mean about, um, under god in the pledge of allegiance, and how people are so opposed to that, but yet they'll let laws be made that enforce religious standards on an entire country. Um, just one, lots of people are anti-gay and anti-gay marriage because they believe that gay people are somehow psychologically damaged, and the gayness has resulted from trauma in their childhood not being close enough to one or the other of the parents, or just a personality defect. And that is also not a good reason, because the American Psychological Association just put out a memo about how untrue that is, and if people listened to, um, institutions that actually did research and studies on these subjects, instead of listening to their neighbors and their friends, and maybe what's popular opinion in their culture in their church, then maybe the world would be seen a little bit differently. I think the church has already changed to adapt to the 21st century. 
I know even as I've grown up, when I was younger I would always go to church every Sunday. And I would get cute little dresses, and matching shoes, and a matching purse. That was every weekend I went to a private school, and I would see all my friends there. And we would just go. But now as I've gotten older, they've made the mass for teenagers. And they cut it down to 30 minutes. People dress a lot more casually. Especially in the summer, people would come in their beach clothes like straight from the beach. You'd see the families running in late. So I think it has become more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to always get dressed up, people are wearing jeans and khakis. Well, khakis are nice too, but it's just a lot more casual compared to that. As for other things, that's the biggest thing I noticed. Like, that's the church I know. I don't know the politics within the church and whatnot. But yeah, that's it. I don't know what kind of minister or reverend he is, but they allow them to get married. [Mm hmm.] Um, I think, like, the whole... [Um] Sexuality is before about being genetic. I think it's genetic. I don't think people just become that way. I think they're born that way. I don't think it has anything to do with the way they're brought up. It might have something to do a little more in this case, but I think it's their genetics. And you can't hide that through a marriage. You could try, but it would usually come out. So I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent this from happening. If they knew about it and were trying to cover it up, then shame on them, but I don't think in all cases they knew. [Do you have any other thoughts concerning the Catholic Church?] Um, no.

I was initially okay with the premise of the Iraq war, but I think that the repercussions of the 9/11 attacks were still very much lingering, and we went to war in Iraq under a pretext, with many indications that we had already been moving towards Iraq. I believe the Bush administration at the time tied the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, and claimed that Saddam Hussein possessed weapons of mass destruction, which was later proven to be false. That really got under my skin, and overall, the Iraq war has been a real sore spot for me. 

I think the Bush administration was very openly lying to the American people and still hasn't owned up to it. Even Colin Powell has come out and said that he wasn't entirely convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he presented it at the UN. To me, that's a serious malfeasance in office, and I think it's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it since at least the 9/11 attacks. They came into office with the intention of going to war, I believe. 

That last part, I forget the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was likely fired from his office. It seems to me that the younger Bush came in with a bloodlust feeling towards Saddam Hussein due to his dad's administration, and I think he was hoping to expand our energy supply in the long run, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. 

Well, I think it's gone on long enough. I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now, though, because there's a good chance the country would lapse into civil war, and more people would die as a result. I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving towards now seems to be like a coalition of nations from the surrounding area, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, coming in to try to restore order. But I'm not entirely sure that's a good idea either because I think in the long term it will also cause more problems because Iraq's sovereignty will become a major issue. 

As it stands, the interim government is dissolving, and from the news reports, I've heard that the Iraqi Parliament is not very effective at all. The Prime Minister doesn't really have control over the political process, and even Muqtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, and we're still dealing with these fractious radical elements vying for control of the government. And I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that.

If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get that bulletin from them. If it wasn't the school that sent the bulletin, then someone went to the school and they have to take action. They can't just let it sit there because then God forbid something happens, they might be able to prevent it. [Right] On the other hand, you don't know what to take seriously because some people just mess around like that. Maybe it could be like the situation we had at school where the experiment went terribly wrong. Maybe it's just a sociology class experiment that didn't go well. I think I forgot the word for a minute. It could be something serious or something very dangerous. What happened here was that something happened and someone overheard someone saying something in the school, then they reported it, and when we finally figured out who the person was, they looked through their Facebook and got worried because there were some things on there that he might have meant as a joke but became serious in the situation. When you put something out on the internet, there's no invasion of privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't put it out. If you don't want someone to find it, don't post it. If you don't want someone to think something about you, you can't control their thoughts. You can't control people's perceptions of what's serious or not. I think school officials shouldn't be friending their students on Myspace and Facebook and monitoring them, and looking through their Facebooks and Myspaces and all those things and Xangas and Live Journals. But if it's brought to their attention, there's no invasion of privacy because it's brought by someone you gave access to. And if there's danger, they have to take it seriously. Like I said, I don't think they should be monitoring phone conversations and texts and IMs. If it's brought to their attention, that's a different story altogether. Yeah, don't. Like a teacher shouldn't make a Facebook or Myspace account under a different name and friend their students because that's the same thing. I wouldn't friend my residents because honestly, I don't want to know if they're going out and partying and then posting their pictures on Facebook. Then that pops up and I'd have to take action. That's not my place, so I don't even want that connection. Not really.

So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy but saying like the qualities of them. So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist, and we've come a long way and change takes time. transformed_texts: I think the Catholic Church needs to change in some ways. They have strong views which are fine but a bit outdated. They have been talking about how the Catholic Church is losing some of its followers and I think it's because the Catholic Church isn't very accepting of a lot of things. For example, gay marriages, abortion, birth control, etc. They have a very strong viewpoint on these things which is understandable. But the problem is if they were to adapt to a bit of a newer way of thinking they wouldn't be worried about losing followers. Some people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because they see their stance on these issues as old-fashioned and so some people are starting to disagree with them on certain subjects. They feel that the Catholic Church has the wrong view on things. The Catholic Church is against abortion, so if you're for abortion you might not be comfortable following a church that teaches it's completely wrong and that you're against it. The same goes for gay marriage, etc. If you believe in it and want to do it or feel strongly about it, you might not want to be in a church that doesn't agree with that. I don't see any reason why women can't be priests or why priests can't be married. But I don't know if that would have prevented what happened. I don't know if they would have done things differently if they were allowed to be married or have women priests. But I don't know if that would have changed things. They did what they did and that didn't seem to be affected. I mean, if they were married would they have done things differently? It's hard to really tell. I don't see why priests can't be married, the Catholic Church says that priests are married to God and devote their whole life to God, but everyone else who has a job in the world has their job and also has their family life and other people they're devoted to, so I don't see why priests can't have both.

I personally don't oppose same-sex marriage. I think people's sexual orientation isn't a conscious choice. So I think gay people shouldn't be blamed for their sexual orientation. I think it's unfair. Because they don't choose their sexual orientation. I think sexual orientation isn't an option. People can't choose whether they're gay or straight. I'm straight, another person is gay, that's how they're born. I think it's not a conscious choice. So I think they shouldn't be blamed. I think the government shouldn't interfere with this issue because it's not a legal issue. It's not a moral issue either. I don't think it's a national security issue. The government shouldn't interfere with personal matters. Everyone should have the right to choose their own life. Gay people should be treated with dignity and respect.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there's not really a good reason not to. Many people think that gay couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's completely different. Gay marriage has many aspects, and it can't be compared to heterosexual marriage. It's like two sides of the same coin - it will never be the other side. However, it's still the same thing. Gay couples have a lot of civil rights that come with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing, where their partner can't be in the room with them if they're sick, and can't visit because they're not technically family. And I think that's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have been done because it's a hot topic these days, and gay couples have the same kind of success rates as heterosexual couples. They have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It's just a relationship, it's the same thing. And I think where a lot of people get hung up on is that gay people aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state, then that shouldn't be an issue. Because I don't understand how people, like Catholics, can get hung up on, "Oh, that's against our religion, and that's morally wrong for us, and we can't approve of that kind of thing." But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. Yeah, they are, they're the same in many ways, like the type of relationship roles played by different partners, and stuff like that. And people worry about adoption issues, and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. And especially about, um, children of gay couples, and how they'll adjust to society, and whether or not they'll be influenced by their parent's sexual orientation choices or not. But well, again, it's kind of new, and stuff, but it's kind of hard to say I'm not sure about the children aspect about adoption, because I think the main drawback to that is, um, how children get treated by their peers, and by other adults in society. Like in New York City, I know they have special schools for children of gay parents, because in public schools in New York City, they get like beaten up. And stuff like that, parents protest to get the child removed from their school, and it's just a kid, I mean, they're gonna have the same points of view, and everything, parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight couples. And so, they can be community involved or not, like heterosexual couples choose to, I mean it's just about personality choices. I think the federal government should be very involved in this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state, I think the amendment should just be the opposite. But well, I think President Bush has very very strong views of his own having to do with his religion. His take on gay marriage actually, um, I think it goes along with his take on abortion, and stem cell research which, um, I think most of the reasons, I'm not sure about this, because honestly I try not to pay attention to politics a lot, but most of the reasons I've heard at least like in the news and stuff are moral reasons, and morality I don't want to say it's negotiable, but it definitely differs from person to person, and to embrace the morality of a certain group in America while totally ignoring the culture and morality concepts of all the rest is unethical, to just go along with what some religious groups believe without taking into account the morality of others is completely hypocritical of the government considering the recent controversy, considering I mean about, um, under god in the pledge of allegiance, and how people are so opposed to that, but yet they'll let laws be made that enforce religious standards on an entire country. Um, just one, lots of people are anti-gay and anti-gay marriage because they believe that gay people are somehow psychologically damaged, and the gayness has resulted from trauma in their childhood not being close enough to one or the other of the parents, or just a personality defect. And that is also not a good reason, because the American Psychological Association just put out a memo about how untrue that is, and if people listened to, um, institutions that actually did research and studies on these subjects, instead of listening to their neighbors and their friends, and maybe what's popular opinion in their culture in their church, then maybe the world would be seen a little bit differently. I think the church has already changed to adapt to the 21st century. 
I know even as I've grown up, when I was younger I would always go to church every Sunday. And I would get cute little dresses, and matching shoes, and a matching purse. That was every weekend I went to a private school, and I would see all my friends there. And we would just go. But now as I've gotten older, they've made the mass for teenagers. And they cut it down to 30 minutes. People dress a lot more casually. Especially in the summer, people would come in their beach clothes like straight from the beach. You'd see the families running in late. So I think it has become more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to always get dressed up, people are wearing jeans and khakis. Well, khakis are nice too, but it's just a lot more casual compared to that. As for other things, that's the biggest thing I noticed. Like, that's the church I know. I don't know the politics within the church and whatnot. But yeah, that's it. [Regarding all the accusations against Catholic priests dealing with pedophilia, do you think these could have been prevented if the church changed, for example, allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry?] I don't think these things could have been avoided. I think also, when they're becoming a priest, it's their choice to become a priest. There are religions that allow them to get married, like Seventh-day Adventists. I don't know what kind of minister or reverend he is, but they allow them to get married. So I know it's a little different, but if they really wanted to practice their faith and be married at the same time, they should maybe think about a different faith. [Can you elaborate on your answer a little bit more?] Um, which part? About... [Um] Just the changing ways. [That it really wouldn't make a difference, I guess.] Oh, about the pedophilia. [Mm hmm.] Um, I think, like, the whole... [Um] Sexuality is before about being genetic. I think it's genetic. I don't think people just become that way. I think they're born that way. I don't think it has anything to do with the way they're brought up. It might have something to do a little more in this case, but I think it's their genetics. And you can't hide that through a marriage. You could try, but it would usually come out. So I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent this from happening. If they knew about it and were trying to cover it up, then shame on them, but I don't think in all cases they knew. [Do you have any other thoughts concerning the Catholic Church?] Um, no.

I was initially okay with the premise of the Iraq war, but I think that the repercussions of the 9/11 attacks were still very much lingering, and we went to war in Iraq under a pretext, with many indications that we had already been moving towards Iraq. I believe the Bush administration at the time tied the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, and claimed that Saddam Hussein possessed weapons of mass destruction, which was later proven to be false. That really got under my skin, and overall, the Iraq war has been a real sore spot for me. 

I think the Bush administration was very openly lying to the American people and still hasn't owned up to it. Even Colin Powell has come out and said that he wasn't entirely convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he presented it at the UN. To me, that's a serious malfeasance in office, and I think it's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it since at least the 9/11 attacks. They came into office with the intention of going to war, I believe. 

That last part, I forget the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was likely fired from his office. It seems to me that the younger Bush came in with a bloodlust feeling towards Saddam Hussein due to his dad's administration, and I think he was hoping to expand our energy supply in the long run, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. 

Well, I think it's gone on long enough. I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now, though, because there's a good chance the country would lapse into civil war, and more people would die as a result. I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving towards now seems to be like a coalition of nations from the surrounding area, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, coming in to try to restore order. But I'm not entirely sure that's a good idea either because I think in the long term it will also cause more problems because Iraq's sovereignty will become a major issue. 

As it stands, the interim government is dissolving, and from the news reports, I've heard that the Iraqi Parliament is not very effective at all. The Prime Minister doesn't really have control over the political process, and even Muqtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, and we're still dealing with these fractious radical elements vying for control of the government. And I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that.

Especially if you're talking about explosions or shootings, people will say something. You can't just let that out and expose it to the public. The internet is open to everyone. When you put something out on the internet, there's no invasion of privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't put it out. If you don't want someone to find it, don't post it. I think there is still gender discrimination in American society. Although it's not just women who are affected, women will find it more difficult in certain specific fields. For example, even though there should be an equal environment, many people still have a hard time finding a job where they can work together with a woman. This is because the social concept has deeply taken root. Many times, women will find they have the qualifications for a certain job, but the board won't choose to promote them to that position because historically women are not often seen in the upper echelons of the business world. The same thing is true for men, such as in the fashion industry or taking care of the family. It's very rare for a man to stay at home and take care of the children. Many people stigmatize this because they think men should be working to make money. This can be very hard on men because they may have always dreamed of staying at home to take care of the children and help their wives' careers thrive, and it's working out fine for them, but society stigmatizes it. In the fashion industry, many people won't take males seriously if they're straight. I'm not sure if that makes sense, but I think it's because males who are into fashion typically have different lifestyles. So if you have the typical male lifestyle and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Wait, how do I really know if you know fashion if it's for a woman? You don't really know what our case is like." Depending on the field of work you're in, I feel like there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset and we've come a long way from the 1800s and made leaps and bounds, but change is slow. So I feel that if we continue at the pace we are now, because women are rising to higher positions and becoming CEOs and getting more accepted in the business world, and it's a slow process, but it's happening and people are starting to accept it more. Just like how men who are stay-at-home dads are becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh, wait, maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works," and um, then for like fashion people will be like, "Oh, wait, maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff," and so they do know like where I'm coming from. So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy but saying like the qualities of them. Because if you force it people are going to resist. And I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that. So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist, and we've come a long way and change takes time. Yes, um, well, I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar may not be the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you may not have the best grammar in the world or even though you may be intelligent but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like, "Well, how do I know you're really what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?" So, yeah, so like sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you and like from gender to gender. I don't know, I guess that's another example, um, not really.

transformed_texts: I think the Catholic Church needs to change in some ways. They have strong views which are fine but a bit outdated. They have been talking about how the Catholic Church is losing some of its followers and I think it's because the Catholic Church isn't very accepting of a lot of things. For example, gay marriages, abortion, birth control, etc. They have a very strong viewpoint on these things which is understandable. But the problem is if they were to adapt to a bit of a newer way of thinking they wouldn't be worried about losing followers. Some people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because they see their stance on these issues as old-fashioned and so some people are starting to disagree with them on certain subjects. They feel that the Catholic Church has the wrong view on things. The Catholic Church is against abortion, so if you're for abortion you might not be comfortable following a church that teaches it's completely wrong and that you're against it. The same goes for gay marriage, etc. If you believe in it and want to do it or feel strongly about it, you might not want to be in a church that doesn't agree with that. I don't see any reason why women can't be priests or why priests can't be married. But I don't know if that would have prevented what happened. I think there is still gender discrimination in American society. Although it's not just women who are affected, women will find it more difficult in certain specific fields. For example, even though there should be an equal environment, many people still have a hard time finding a job where they can work together with a woman. This is because the social concept has deeply taken root. Many times, women will find they have the qualifications for a certain job, but the board won't choose to promote them to that position because historically women are not often seen in the upper echelons of the business world. The same thing is true for men, such as in the fashion industry or taking care of the family. It's very rare for a man to stay at home and take care of the children. Many people stigmatize this because they think men should be working to make money. This can be very hard on men because they may have always dreamed of staying at home to take care of the children and help their wives' careers thrive, and it's working out fine for them, but society stigmatizes it. In the fashion industry, many people won't take males seriously if they're straight. I'm not sure if that makes sense, but I think it's because males who are into fashion typically have different lifestyles. So if you have the typical male lifestyle and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Wait, how do I really know if you know fashion if it's for a woman? You don't really know what our case is like." Depending on the field of work you're in, I feel like there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset and we've come a long way from the 1800s and made leaps and bounds, but change is slow. So I feel that if we continue at the pace we are now, because women are rising to higher positions and becoming CEOs and getting more accepted in the business world, and it's a slow process, but it's happening and people are starting to accept it more. Just like how men who are stay-at-home dads are becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh, wait, maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works," and um, then for like fashion people will be like, "Oh, wait, maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff," and so they do know like where I'm coming from. So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy but saying like the qualities of them. Because if you force it people are going to resist. And I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that. So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist, and we've come a long way and change takes time. Yes, um, well, I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar may not be the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you may not have the best grammar in the world or even though you may be intelligent but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like, "Well, how do I know you're really what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?" So, yeah, so like sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you and like from gender to gender. I don't know, I guess that's another example, um, not really.

When you put something on the internet, it's like an open forum.  It's totally public.  You can't control it.  I mean, as an RA, I've actually had to deal with this.  Uh, when you put something out there, it affects people's opinions of you.  If you're talking about blowing things up or shootings, someone's gonna say something.  You can't put that out there.  It's going to be seen by everybody.  If you're friends with that person on Myspace, you get that bulletin.  Obviously, it wasn't the school that got the bulletin.  Someone went to the school and they have to act on that.  They can't just let it sit there because then God forbid something happens, they could have prevented it.  [Right]  On the other hand, you don't know what to take seriously because some people just fool around like that.  I mean, it could be like the situation we had at school.  It could be an experiment that went terribly wrong for a sociology class.  I think that word I couldn't remember for a minute, uh.  And it could also be something very serious.  I think what happened here was that something happened and someone overheard someone saying something in the school and then they called it in and when we finally found out who the person was, they looked through their Facebook and got worried because there were some certain things on there that he may have meant as a joke.  But in light of the situation, it became very serious.  When you put stuff out into the public forum of the internet, there's really no invasion of privacy that happens.  If you don't want it out there, don't put it there.  If you don't want someone to find it, if you don't want someone to think something of you, you can't tell them what to think.  You can't tell people what to take seriously or not.  I mean, I don't think school officials should be friending their students on Myspace and Facebook and stalking them, and going through Facebooks and Myspaces and all those things and Xangas and Live Journals.  But if it is brought to the attention of the school officials, there's really no invasion of privacy there because it's brought by someone who you gave access to it.  And if there's danger, they have to take it seriously.  I mean, like I said, I don't think they should be monitoring phone conversations and texts and IMs.  If it's brought to their attention, then it's something completely different.  Uh, yeah, don't think, like, a teacher should not make a Facebook or a Myspace account under a different name and friend their students because then that's just the same thing.  I wouldn't friend my residents because, frankly, I don't want to know if they're going out and drinking and then posting their pictures on Facebook.  Then that pops up and I have to see that and I have to do something about it.  It's not my place, so I don't even want that connection.  Um, not really.

I think the war has been dragged out for too long. 
I believe the initial intention was good. 
However, I think we've lost sight of that intention a long time ago. 
We're just maybe doing it to prove that we're a superpower in the world. 
I just think the initial motives were questionable, related to George Bush's father's previous conflicts with Saddam Hussein. 
If the original intention was to give democracy to a country without a fair political system, I think that would be a fair motivation, but if there were personal issues involved, I don't think it would be fair. 
But I think it's been dragged out for too long. 
If our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, I think that's a just purpose and a good reason for the war. 
However, I don't think our reasons have been deteriorated and misconceived over time. 
It seems like we're still at war just for the sake of war, and we don't want to end this thing without a decisive victory or conclusion. 
I think it's gone on long enough, and it should stop. 
Their government and officials will have to fend for themselves eventually. 
I think that time has come. 
We've been draining our economy for a long time, spending billions of dollars, while we have our own wars, such as poverty and other issues, that we should be addressing. 
I think it's a heavy burden on our economy, as the purpose has been stretched to absurdity. 
They're spending billions and billions of dollars. 
War shouldn't be in our long-term budget. 
There are obviously issues like poverty, internal improvements, public roads, schools, etc. 
We have a lot of problems that need to be solved, such as healthcare, which I think could be better spent on. 
Right now, that money is being spent to have some of our citizens killed in a foreign country at a war that we've lost the reason for.

We feel that there's still a problem of gender discrimination in the United States. I think it's not just a women's issue. Different fields of work have different levels of gender discrimination. I feel that women face more difficulties in many areas. For example, even in a society that strives for equality, many people find it hard to accept women as their superiors. This is because society's attitude towards women has been shaped over time. If a woman has the qualifications for a certain position, but her superiors still won't promote her due to a historical lack of women in top business positions, that's a problem. The same thing happens to men, especially in industries like fashion. Generally, men don't stay home to take care of the kids, and society mocks this choice. People think that men should be the primary breadwinner, not stay home to take care of the kids. However, in some cases, it's the opposite – the wife has a better job, and the husband stays home to take care of the kids, yet society still mocks this choice.

In the fashion industry, people don't take men seriously. They think that if a man is into fashion, he's somehow different from women. They assume that men who are into fashion must have different tastes or lifestyles, and that they can't truly understand women's needs. They think that other men are different, and that they can't possibly understand women's needs. This is why people are discriminated against based on where they're from or their gender. Changing this is difficult because society has formed its own set of stereotypes. We've made a lot of progress, especially with women rising to top business positions and becoming CEOs, but change is slow. If we continue at our current pace, women will keep rising to the top, and people will start to accept this. Similarly, men staying home to take care of the kids is becoming more accepted because people are starting to realize that women might have better jobs. People in the fashion industry are also starting to realize that people's needs might not be what they think they are. So, we need to promote the qualities of people who are often discriminated against without being too pushy. If you try to force it, people will resist. If we're doing everything we can already, we don't need to do anything else because if we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. We've made a lot of progress, and change takes time.

It's also possible that our society will discriminate against you because of where you're from or your gender. I think the war has been dragged out for too long. 
I believe the initial intention was good. 
However, I think we've lost sight of that intention a long time ago. 
We're just maybe doing it to prove that we're a superpower in the world. 
I just think the initial motives were questionable, related to George Bush's father's previous conflicts with Saddam Hussein. 
If the original intention was to give democracy to a country without a fair political system, I think that would be a fair motivation, but if there were personal issues involved, I don't think it would be fair. 
But I think it's been dragged out for too long. 
If our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, I think that's a just purpose and a good reason for the war. 
However, I don't think our reasons have been deteriorated and misconceived over time. 
It seems like we're still at war just for the sake of war, and we don't want to end this thing without a decisive victory or conclusion. 
I think it's gone on long enough, and it should stop. 
Their government and officials will have to fend for themselves eventually. 
I think that time has come. 
We've been draining our economy for a long time, spending billions of dollars, while we have our own wars, such as poverty and other issues, that we should be addressing. 
I think it's a heavy burden on our economy, as the purpose has been stretched to absurdity. 
They're spending billions and billions of dollars. 
War shouldn't be in our long-term budget. 
There are obviously issues like poverty, internal improvements, public roads, schools, etc. 
We have a lot of problems that need to be solved, such as healthcare, which I think could be better spent on. 
Right now, that money is being spent to have some of our citizens killed in a foreign country at a war that we've lost the reason for.

We feel that there's still a problem of gender discrimination in the United States. I think it's not just a women's issue. Different fields of work have different levels of gender discrimination. I feel that women face more difficulties in many areas. For example, even in a society that strives for equality, many people find it hard to accept women as their superiors. This is because society's attitude towards women has been shaped over time. If a woman has the qualifications for a certain position, but her superiors still won't promote her due to a historical lack of women in top business positions, that's a problem. The same thing happens to men, especially in industries like fashion. Generally, men don't stay home to take care of the kids, and society mocks this choice. People think that men should be the primary breadwinner, not stay home to take care of the kids. However, in some cases, it's the opposite – the wife has a better job, and the husband stays home to take care of the kids, yet society still mocks this choice.

In the fashion industry, people don't take men seriously. They think that if a man is into fashion, he's somehow different from women. They assume that men who are into fashion must have different tastes or lifestyles, and that they can't truly understand women's needs. They think that other men are different, and that they can't possibly understand women's needs. This is why people are discriminated against based on where they're from or their gender. Changing this is difficult because society has formed its own set of stereotypes. We've made a lot of progress, especially with women rising to top business positions and becoming CEOs, but change is slow. If we continue at our current pace, women will keep rising to the top, and people will start to accept this. Similarly, men staying home to take care of the kids is becoming more accepted because people are starting to realize that women might have better jobs. People in the fashion industry are also starting to realize that people's needs might not be what they think they are. So, we need to promote the qualities of people who are often discriminated against without being too pushy. If you try to force it, people will resist. If we're doing everything we can already, we don't need to do anything else because if we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. We've made a lot of progress, and change takes time.

It's also possible that our society will discriminate against you because of where you're from or your gender. For example, if you're from a rural area and your grammar isn't great, but you're extremely intelligent, and you work your way up to be a CEO, other men might look down on you and think, "How do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put together a sentence?" Or if you're intelligent but your grammar isn't great, other men might look down on you. So, our society might discriminate against you because of your gender and where you're from.

I grew up in a Christian family, so homosexuality is a gray area for me. 
Because I have many gay friends, I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, but I believe it should be legalized. 
I don't think it should be a national issue. 
However, I think it should be up to each state to decide rather than the president.

A lot of states are democratic and a lot of states are republican. 
Obviously, democratic states will be in favor of gay marriage. 
If you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about the issue. 
I don't think you should disagree with the state's decision to legalize gay marriage, as you chose to live there.

I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I believe it should be legalized based on each state's discretion.

I actually already answered that. 
I don't think Bush should be able to decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. 
I think it should be up to individual states to decide whether they want to legalize it. 
I don't agree with his ban on it.

I just think that Bush doesn't live in every single state, so he shouldn't be able to decide how each state should run itself. 
I think some things should be left up to each individual state. 
Plus, he'll be out of office in about two years. 
If a democratic president decides to lift the ban on gay marriage, it's just going to go back and forth. 
It should just be up to each individual state, because they're the ones who will have to live with that decision, not the president.

Someone went to the school and they have to act on that.  They can't just let it sit there because then God forbid something happens, they could have prevented it.  [Right]  On the other hand, you don't know what to take seriously because some people just fool around like that.  I mean, it could be like the situation we had at school.  It could be an experiment that went terribly wrong for a sociology class.  I think that word I couldn't remember for a minute, uh.  And it could also be something very serious.  I think what happened here was that something happened and someone overheard someone saying something in the school and then they called it in and when we finally found out who the person was, they looked through their Facebook and got worried because there were some certain things on there that he may have meant as a joke.  But in light of the situation, it became very serious.  When you put stuff out into the public forum of the internet, there's really no invasion of privacy that happens. We feel that there's still a problem of gender discrimination in the United States. I think it's not just a women's issue. Different fields of work have different levels of gender discrimination. I feel that women face more difficulties in many areas. For example, even in a society that strives for equality, many people find it hard to accept women as their superiors. This is because society's attitude towards women has been shaped over time. If a woman has the qualifications for a certain position, but her superiors still won't promote her due to a historical lack of women in top business positions, that's a problem. The same thing happens to men, especially in industries like fashion. Generally, men don't stay home to take care of the kids, and society mocks this choice. People think that men should be the primary breadwinner, not stay home to take care of the kids. However, in some cases, it's the opposite – the wife has a better job, and the husband stays home to take care of the kids, yet society still mocks this choice.

In the fashion industry, people don't take men seriously. They think that if a man is into fashion, he's somehow different from women. They assume that men who are into fashion must have different tastes or lifestyles, and that they can't truly understand women's needs. They think that other men are different, and that they can't possibly understand women's needs. This is why people are discriminated against based on where they're from or their gender. Changing this is difficult because society has formed its own set of stereotypes. We've made a lot of progress, especially with women rising to top business positions and becoming CEOs, but change is slow. If we continue at our current pace, women will keep rising to the top, and people will start to accept this. Similarly, men staying home to take care of the kids is becoming more accepted because people are starting to realize that women might have better jobs. People in the fashion industry are also starting to realize that people's needs might not be what they think they are. So, we need to promote the qualities of people who are often discriminated against without being too pushy. If you try to force it, people will resist. If we're doing everything we can already, we don't need to do anything else because if we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. We've made a lot of progress, and change takes time.

It's also possible that our society will discriminate against you because of where you're from or your gender. For example, if you're from a rural area and your grammar isn't great, but you're extremely intelligent, and you work your way up to be a CEO, other men might look down on you and think, "How do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put together a sentence?" Or if you're intelligent but your grammar isn't great, other men might look down on you. So, our society might discriminate against you because of your gender and where you're from.

I think this war has been prolonged for too long. The initial purpose was good, to restore democracy in another country. But now I think we have lost sight of that initial purpose. We may be doing it just to prove that we are a superpower in the world, just to prove ourselves. Perhaps the motives were questionable due to the problems with Saddam Hussein at the time.

If the initial purpose was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would be a fair motivation. But if there were personal vendettas involved, that wouldn't be fair.

I think we conveyed our purpose when we first started the war, and that in itself was a statement. But the fact that it has gone on for over a year is too long.

If our purpose was to save a country ruled by a tyrant, I think that's a justifiable reason for the war. But I think our reason has been distorted over time. It seems like we're still at war for the sake of war. We don't just want to end the war, we want to win.

I think this war has gone on for too long. Their government officials will have to fend for themselves eventually. I think that time has come. We've been draining our own economy for a long time, spending billions of dollars. We have our own wars, such as poverty, education problems, road construction, schools, and healthcare, that we should prioritize. War shouldn't be a long-term expense.

We have a lot of problems that need to be solved, such as poverty, education, highway construction, schools, and healthcare. The money we're spending on the war could be better spent on more meaningful things. Now that money is being spent on a war in a foreign country, causing the loss of our citizens. I think that's all.

I mean, we only have this and then one more time I get to talk about the Iraq War. I mean, I feel embarrassed saying this, but I hate joining the bandwagon of people who say they were against it from the beginning. I was, but it's not really important anymore because everyone in the world thinks it was a bad idea, except within the administration, because they don't want to admit they were wrong. And, I mean, just look at the recent polls. They've done United States polls, Iraqi polls, and global polls, and I mean, no, about seventy-five to eighty percent of the world's population thinks it was a bad idea. Eighty percent of Iraqis, seventy percent of troops stationed there. It's like the US troops stationed there now think it was a dumb idea and we should pull out within a year. I don't know, it's just been a complete disaster from before we even went in. It was already a disaster, and now pulling out is also going to be a disaster. There's really no easy way to deal with the Middle East anymore. I mean, I think it's just the cultural clash between the United States and the Middle Eastern states. I mean, it's just too big of a gap for this administration, or any administration, to understand. They think they can just bring democracy into an area where it shouldn't exist. Like that's not the way that this totally different group of people would choose to run their lives. I mean, sure, Saddam was a bad guy, no one's arguing that. But, I mean, you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country that's going to turn into just a complete disaster, like quicksand when we went in. I don't even know what to say about it. I don't really see a reason to stay in there. I mean, I'm sure the administration is thinking some hopeful ideas about why it's better to stay in there, and the problems that might arise from us pulling out, I don't agree with them. I haven't heard a legitimate reason why we should stay in any longer than we should. I mean, if they want to gradually pull out over the course of a year or maybe a little longer than a year, I guess I wouldn't have a problem with that. But, I just don't see a reason why we shouldn't just leave now. I mean, I read a statistic a little while ago that eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year, and at least a quarter of them think we should just leave now. And like these are the people we're trying to save, we're trying to help, telling us to leave. I think they might know better than that. And at least if we ask them should we leave and they say yes, then you know it's not on us if something happens. You know, if it completely falls apart, we could say, "We wanted to stay in, but you guys made the decision to leave." Then, you know, at least we'll be the good guys, kind of. Not really, no. We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but, you know, it'll be better than where we stand right now.

I think there is still a problem of gender discrimination in the United States, especially in certain specific fields of work.  Although it's not just women who face these problems, I think women face more difficulties in certain fields because, even if society promotes equality, a lot of people have a hard time accepting a woman in a leadership position.  The values that have been cultivated in society for a long time make it difficult for people to accept women in leadership positions in the workplace.  Sometimes women will see a job that is suitable for them and have the necessary qualifications, but are refused promotion to a higher position because of historical reasons.  The same thing happens to men, especially in the fashion industry and as stay-at-home dads.  Society tends to expect men to be the main breadwinners of the family and looks down on them when they decide to be stay-at-home dads, because they think they should be working.  This makes it difficult for men because their dream is to be with their kids and help raise them, and maybe their wife has a better job and it works out fine for them.  However, society looks down on them for their choice.  Also, men in the fashion industry may not be taken seriously because they are men.  Typically, men who are into fashion have different lifestyles, so if you have a typical lifestyle as a man and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for women?  You don't really know what our case is like.  Like those other guys."  Depending on the field of work you're in, I think there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S.  To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset, and we've made great progress from the 1800s, but change is slow.  So I feel that if we continue working at our current pace because women are rising to higher positions, becoming CEOs, and getting more accepted in the business world, and it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more, and just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh, wait, maybe the female does have the better job, or she wants to be the one who works."  And, um, then for like fashion, people will be like, "Oh, wait, maybe they're listening to like their female friends or their wives, and stuff," and so they do know where I'm coming from.  So I guess you kinda have to, in a way, promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um, saying like the qualities of them.  Because if you force it, people will resist.  And I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that.  So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done, because if you do it too fast, it's like people will resist, and we've come a long way, and change takes time.  Yes.  Um.  Well, I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from.  Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent, and you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down on you and be like, "Well, how do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?"  So, yeah.  So, like, sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender.  And I don't know.  I guess that'd be another example.  Um, not really.

At first, I was all for war because I was affected by nine eleven personally. I thought we should go over there and cause just as much chaos as they did here. But I think since it was such an emotional thing that happened, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long run. We kind of just went over there unprepared without a plan. I really think that it backfired on us. I was all for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it did anything. I think the people over there, as long as they're fighting with each other, they can't be fighting with us as well. Like, I don't think us being over there is going to do anything if they're fighting with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of nine eleven, I've almost just stopped caring about what goes on over there. I just don't care. I think sometimes I don't even think they're human. I don't know, they fight with each other and they can't do anything themselves, so I really don't care. We definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face over there. And it's also bad because war for them is very different from war for us. They're just like savage people when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out of there, and I think that's fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. We just, I think we were just more hyped up than anything. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle, and I think President Bush just went over there because pretty much the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. I also think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. But at the time, I see where he was coming from. We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say, "Okay, let's rebuild and that's it." So, I don't think we could have let it go, but I think we could have had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't have unity. They didn't know what they were going into for, so I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn in there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And, honestly, I don't have anything else to say. Our discussion has definitely gone on long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. We've made progress, but not enough to stay in there. And I think no matter how long we stay in there, once we leave, it's just going to collapse. We can't stay over there forever, so I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying over there.

I mean, we only have this and then one more time I get to talk about the Iraq War. I mean, I feel embarrassed saying this, but I hate joining the bandwagon of people who say they were against it from the beginning. I was, but it's not really important anymore because everyone in the world thinks it was a bad idea, except within the administration, because they don't want to admit they were wrong. And, I mean, just look at the recent polls. They've done United States polls, Iraqi polls, and global polls, and I mean, no, about seventy-five to eighty percent of the world's population thinks it was a bad idea. Eighty percent of Iraqis, seventy percent of troops stationed there. It's like the US troops stationed there now think it was a dumb idea and we should pull out within a year. I don't know, it's just been a complete disaster from before we even went in. It was already a disaster, and now pulling out is also going to be a disaster. There's really no easy way to deal with the Middle East anymore. I mean, I think it's just the cultural clash between the United States and the Middle Eastern states. I mean, it's just too big of a gap for this administration, or any administration, to understand. They think they can just bring democracy into an area where it shouldn't exist. Like that's not the way that this totally different group of people would choose to run their lives. I mean, sure, Saddam was a bad guy, no one's arguing that. But, I mean, you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country that's going to turn into just a complete disaster, like quicksand when we went in. I don't even know what to say about it. I don't really see a reason to stay in there. I mean, I'm sure the administration is thinking some hopeful ideas about why it's better to stay in there, and the problems that might arise from us pulling out, I don't agree with them. I haven't heard a legitimate reason why we should stay in any longer than we should. I mean, if they want to gradually pull out over the course of a year or maybe a little longer than a year, I guess I wouldn't have a problem with that. But, I just don't see a reason why we shouldn't just leave now. I mean, I read a statistic a little while ago that eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year, and at least a quarter of them think we should just leave now. And like these are the people we're trying to save, we're trying to help, telling us to leave. I think they might know better than that. And at least if we ask them should we leave and they say yes, then you know it's not on us if something happens. You know, if it completely falls apart, we could say, "We wanted to stay in, but you guys made the decision to leave." Then, you know, at least we'll be the good guys, kind of. Not really, no. We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but, you know, it'll be better than where we stand right now.

I think there is still a problem of gender discrimination in the United States, especially in certain specific fields of work.  Although it's not just women who face these problems, I think women face more difficulties in certain fields because, even if society promotes equality, a lot of people have a hard time accepting a woman in a leadership position.  The values that have been cultivated in society for a long time make it difficult for people to accept women in leadership positions in the workplace.  Sometimes women will see a job that is suitable for them and have the necessary qualifications, but are refused promotion to a higher position because of historical reasons.  The same thing happens to men, especially in the fashion industry and as stay-at-home dads.  Society tends to expect men to be the main breadwinners of the family and looks down on them when they decide to be stay-at-home dads, because they think they should be working.  This makes it difficult for men because their dream is to be with their kids and help raise them, and maybe their wife has a better job and it works out fine for them.  However, society looks down on them for their choice.  Also, men in the fashion industry may not be taken seriously because they are men.  Typically, men who are into fashion have different lifestyles, so if you have a typical lifestyle as a man and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for women?  You don't really know what our case is like.  Like those other guys."  Depending on the field of work you're in, I think there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S.  To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset, and we've made great progress from the 1800s, but change is slow.  So I feel that if we continue working at our current pace because women are rising to higher positions, becoming CEOs, and getting more accepted in the business world, and it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more, and just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh, wait, maybe the female does have the better job, or she wants to be the one who works."  And, um, then for like fashion, people will be like, "Oh, wait, maybe they're listening to like their female friends or their wives, and stuff," and so they do know where I'm coming from.  So I guess you kinda have to, in a way, promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um, saying like the qualities of them.  Because if you force it, people will resist.  And I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that.  So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done, because if you do it too fast, it's like people will resist, and we've come a long way, and change takes time.  Yes.  Um.  Well, I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from.  Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent, and you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down on you and be like, "Well, how do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?"  So, yeah.  So, like, sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender.  And I don't know.  I guess that'd be another example.  Um, not really.

At first, I was all for war because I was affected by nine eleven personally. I thought we should go over there and cause just as much chaos as they did here. But I think since it was such an emotional thing that happened, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long run. We kind of just went over there unprepared without a plan. I really think that it backfired on us. I was all for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it did anything. I think the people over there, as long as they're fighting with each other, they can't be fighting with us as well. Like, I don't think us being over there is going to do anything if they're fighting with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of nine eleven, I've almost just stopped caring about what goes on over there. I just don't care. I think sometimes I don't even think they're human. I don't know, they fight with each other and they can't do anything themselves, so I really don't care. We definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face over there. And it's also bad because war for them is very different from war for us. They're just like savage people when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out of there, and I think that's fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. We just, I think we were just more hyped up than anything. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle, and I think President Bush just went over there because pretty much the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. I also think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. But at the time, I see where he was coming from. We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say, "Okay, let's rebuild and that's it." So, I don't think we could have let it go, but I think we could have had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't have unity. They didn't know what they were going into for, so I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn in there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And, honestly, I don't have anything else to say. Our discussion has definitely gone on long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. We've made progress, but not enough to stay in there. And I think no matter how long we stay in there, once we leave, it's just going to collapse. We can't stay over there forever, so I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying over there.

I think in some ways, the Catholic Church needs to change. Their views are a bit outdated. The Catholic Church has been talking about how they are losing some of their followers. I think this is because the Catholic Church is not very open to many things. For example, gay marriage, abortion, birth control - they have very strong views on them. Their views on these things might be reasonable, but some are outdated. If they could adapt to some more modern ways of thinking, they wouldn't be afraid of losing followers.

Many people are starting to feel disenchanted with the Catholic Church because of their views on these things. Some people are starting to disagree with them on these issues. So, I think the Catholic Church's views are probably wrong. The Catholic Church is against abortion, so if you support abortion, you might not want to join a church that teaches it's completely wrong and you're going against it.

Similarly, if you support gay marriage, you might not want to join a church that doesn't agree with that. The Catholic Church doesn't allow women to be priests, so if you support that change, you might not want to join a church that opposes women priests.

I don't think there's any reason why priests can't get married or women can't be priests. They say priests are already married to God and have completely dedicated their lives to God. But almost everyone has their job and family life, and they care about other things. So, I don't think priests can't have both their work and family life.

I haven't heard a legitimate reason why we should stay in any longer than we should. But, I just don't see a reason why we shouldn't just leave now.
