I think there is still a problem of gender discrimination in the United States, especially in certain specific fields of work.  Although it's not just women who face these problems, I think women face more difficulties in certain fields because, even if society promotes equality, a lot of people have a hard time accepting a woman in a leadership position.  The values that have been cultivated in society for a long time make it difficult for people to accept women in leadership positions in the workplace.  Sometimes women will see a job that is suitable for them and have the necessary qualifications, but are refused promotion to a higher position because of historical reasons.  The same thing happens to men, especially in the fashion industry and as stay-at-home dads.  Society tends to expect men to be the main breadwinners of the family and looks down on them when they decide to be stay-at-home dads, because they think they should be working.  This makes it difficult for men because their dream is to be with their kids and help raise them, and maybe their wife has a better job and it works out fine for them.  However, society looks down on them for their choice.  Also, men in the fashion industry may not be taken seriously because they are men.  Typically, men who are into fashion have different lifestyles, so if you have a typical lifestyle as a man and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, "Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for women?  You don't really know what our case is like.  Like those other guys."  Depending on the field of work you're in, I think there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S.  To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset, and we've made great progress from the 1800s, but change is slow.  So I feel that if we continue working at our current pace because women are rising to higher positions, becoming CEOs, and getting more accepted in the business world, and it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more, and just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, "Oh, wait, maybe the female does have the better job, or she wants to be the one who works."  And, um, then for like fashion, people will be like, "Oh, wait, maybe they're listening to like their female friends or their wives, and stuff," and so they do know where I'm coming from.  So I guess you kinda have to, in a way, promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um, saying like the qualities of them.  Because if you force it, people will resist.  And I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that.  So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done, because if you do it too fast, it's like people will resist, and we've come a long way, and change takes time.  Yes.  Um.  Well, I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from.  Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent, and you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down on you and be like, "Well, how do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?"  So, yeah.  So, like, sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender.  And I don't know.  I guess that'd be another example.  Um, not really.

At first, I was all for war because I was affected by nine eleven personally. I thought we should go over there and cause just as much chaos as they did here. But I think since it was such an emotional thing that happened, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long run. We kind of just went over there unprepared without a plan. I really think that it backfired on us. I was all for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it did anything. I think the people over there, as long as they're fighting with each other, they can't be fighting with us as well. Like, I don't think us being over there is going to do anything if they're fighting with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of nine eleven, I've almost just stopped caring about what goes on over there. I just don't care. I think sometimes I don't even think they're human. I don't know, they fight with each other and they can't do anything themselves, so I really don't care. We definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face over there. And it's also bad because war for them is very different from war for us. They're just like savage people when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out of there, and I think that's fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. We just, I think we were just more hyped up than anything. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle, and I think President Bush just went over there because pretty much the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. I also think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. But at the time, I see where he was coming from. We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say, "Okay, let's rebuild and that's it." So, I don't think we could have let it go, but I think we could have had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't have unity. They didn't know what they were going into for, so I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn in there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And, honestly, I don't have anything else to say. Our discussion has definitely gone on long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. We've made progress, but not enough to stay in there. And I think no matter how long we stay in there, once we leave, it's just going to collapse. We can't stay over there forever, so I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying over there.

Okay, the war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war. Before invading Iraq, I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the 9/11 terrorist attacks when in reality there wasn't much of a connection between the two. However, the government made it seem like there was a connection and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the 9/11 terrorist attacks and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003. Um, I'm against war, especially a preemptive strike, I was against that. And I think the war in Iraq is kind of a repeat of the Vietnam War in many ways. The government should have learned from past mistakes that they made with the Vietnam War. I mean, a tremendous amount of American soldiers have died and that's horrible. What they were doing was removing the countries government and I really don't think the government was prepared for the aftermath and the void of power and the chaos that was going to occur. Um, and the government and so the United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, which is kind of a similar thing they were trying to do in Vietnam. They were trying to push out Communists and uphold or implement democracy. And I think that the government, the US government should have known that it was going to be a long and hard ordeal that probably wasn't going to be a clear victory like it wasn't a clear victory in Vietnam because no matter how many people may have supported the invasion or no matter how many Iraqis may have wanted the US to come in there's going to be a large number of insurgents and it's hard to put them down when you're not fighting an actual army. You're fighting the citizens of the country. So I think that the government, the US government should have planned for all possible outcomes. I think the government was not as prepared as it should have been, I mean, they didn't really plan for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government. I mean, we're still there today, almost the end of 2006 and we're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and Iraqi police forces to be able to police their own country and it's a long process. And I just think that the US government in a way tried to deceive the American people in making them think it would be a short successful stay in Iraq. I mean, we shouldn't be naive in thinking that because it takes a number of years to implement a new form of government and to have it become successful. I mean, in our own country, democracy was a long struggle and to be able to get to the powerful government we are today was a long struggle and there was lots of tension and there was civil war. Um, it's just not an easy thing to do and I think the government, the US government made it seem like it was a relatively easy thing to do. And so, the war in Iraq, well, that's a difficult decision to make because once you go in there and we've been in there for so long, how can we abandon these people? I mean, we're the ones that took away their government and their way of life so how can we abandon them now? So, it's probably something that we should try to see to its finish but again, there's also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties and how much is too much to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq. I mean, going back to the whole reason for invading Iraq, I mean, if we're invading Iraq and making it a democratic nation, why is it just Iraq? Why aren't we doing this to all these other countries? I think the big reason for that is the oil issue. It's all about the money and controlling resources. I mean, another one of the predispositions before going into war was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but no weapons of mass destruction were ever actually found. And yet, places like North Korea, we actually knew they had weapons of mass destruction, but we're not making any attacks against them. So, I don't think the US government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions. Let's see, um, I just hope that it ends soon and there will be peace there soon but probably not.

I think there is still sexism in the United States. It's not just about women; I think it's about the specific field of work you're in. I believe women face more difficulties in certain fields because, even with the theory of equality, many people still have a hard time accepting female leaders. This is because society has had a preconceived notion for a long time. Therefore, women often find themselves qualified for a job, but are rejected, because people think women shouldn't be in high positions. Similarly, men face similar challenges in certain fields, such as fashion and childcare. Usually, the parent is the woman, and the man is expected to be the breadwinner. If a man chooses to stay home and care for the children, society looks down on them: "You should be the one earning money for the family." This puts a lot of pressure on them, as they may have originally wanted to be the primary caregivers, while their wives have better jobs. And in the fashion industry, people will doubt a man's authenticity: "You're not a true fashion enthusiast; your style doesn't fit the industry standards." People question his professionalism, worrying he can't understand women's needs. This also relates to geographical background, because some people may have regional cultural biases against women or men. To change this, we need to gradually promote understanding and acceptance of different groups. We need to avoid forced promotion and instead showcase their strengths and abilities. If we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. So, we need to gradually push for this change, allowing people to slowly accept it. We've made great progress, and change takes time. Actually, besides sexism, geographical background can also lead to other forms of discrimination.

And, I mean, so when you're looking at municipalities that are financially in trouble, I mean a lot of them just philosophically aren't willing to make that kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them, like a lot of communities are rightfully so against marijuana that they don't want to do that. I mean, so I think it's important because I mean marijuana isn't something that you just want out and out to be everywhere all over the streets and stuff. I mean for a variety of reasons, but there's this whole like financial element to it as well. And I think that should be fine for us, I think we should just leave and that's really it. transformed_texts: I think that in some ways the Catholic Church needs to change. They have a lot of views that I think the Catholic Church isn't very accepting of a lot of things, which is why they're losing some of their followers. The Catholic Church has very strong views on things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which I think is fine, but they're a bit old-fashioned in some ways. So I think if they were to adapt to some newer styles of thinking, they wouldn't be worried about losing their followers. I've heard that a lot of people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church a bit because of their views on these issues. Some people are starting to disagree with the Catholic Church on certain subjects, so they feel that the Catholic Church has the wrong views on things. I mean, the Catholic Church is against abortion, so if you're for abortion you might not feel comfortable in a following where that was taught to be completely wrong and something you were against. It's similar with gay marriage, where if that's something you believe in and want to do or feel strongly about, you might not want to be in a following where they disagree with that. I don't see any reason why they can't have female priests or that priests can't be married, but I'm not sure if that would have necessarily prevented these problems. I don't think it would have changed anything, actually. I don't think they would have done anything differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were female priests. The Catholic Church says that priests are married to God and devoted to their whole life, but I don't see why regular people can't have both a job and a family life, so I don't see why priests can't have both.

I personally don't object to same-sex marriage. Well, I think it's not a conscious choice, whether you're born that way or whatever. I don't think gay people should be held accountable for their sexual orientation. So, I think it's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married but not two people of the same sex. It seems like it's not a choice, like they don't have a choice in how they are. I was born straight, and another person is born gay, it doesn't seem like it's a conscious choice that they should be held responsible for. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal issue, I don't know if I want to call it a moral issue. I don't think they should be judged or put on a stage, like they made a wrong decision or choice or whatever. So I don't think the federal government really has any say. It's hard. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it has nothing to do with the security of our country, it has nothing to do with moral concerns or anything like that, it just seems like they're out of place. They don't seem to have the right to intervene in people's lives, and that's just who they are - like they were born that way or at least that's what I think. And I think they shouldn't be punished for that.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because basically there's not a good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's so different. And there are so many different aspects to it that it could never be considered the same. It's just like two different sides of the same coin. Heads will never be tails, but it's like the same thing. There are a lot of civil rights that go along with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing where your primary or your next of kin can be in the room with you if you're sick and can visit. And I think that's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. And a lot of scientific studies have been done because it's a hot topic these days, and homosexual couples have the same kind of rates of success, they have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It's just it's a relationship, it's the same thing. And I think where a lot of people get hung up is homosexuals aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state then that shouldn't be an issue. Because I don't understand where people like Catholics can get hung up on oh well that's against our religion and that's morally wrong for us and we can't approve of that sort of thing. But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union why not allow them a marriage. It's like segregation, separate but unequal. Yeah, they are, they're the same in many ways like the type of relationship roles played by different partners and stuff like that. And people worry about like adoption issues and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. And especially about, um, children of gay couples and how they'll adjust to society and whether or not they'll, um, be influenced by their parent's, um, sexual orientation choices or not. But well again it's kind of new and stuff, but it's kind of hard to say I'm not sure about the children aspect about adoption. Because I think the main drawback to that is, um, how children get treated by their peers and by other adults in society. Like in New York City, I know they um, they have special schools for children of gay parents, because in public schools in New York City they get, um, beaten up. And stuff like that, parents protest to get the child removed from their school, and it's just a kid, I mean, they're gonna have the same points of view and everything, parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight couples. And so they can be community involved or not like heterosexual couples choose to, I mean it's just about personality choices. I think the federal government should be very involved in this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state, I think the amendment should just be the opposite. But well I think President Bush has very very strong views of his own having to do with his religion. Well, his um, his take on gay marriage actually um, I think it goes along with his take on abortion and stem cell research which, um, I think most of the reasons I'm not sure about this, because honestly I try not to pay attention to politics a lot, but most of the reasons I've heard at least like in the news and stuff are moral reasons, and morality I don't want to say it's negotiable, but it definitely differs from person to person, and to embrace the morality of a certain group in America while totally ignoring the culture and um, morality concepts of all the rest is unethical. To just go along with what some religious groups believe without taking into account to go along with what religious groups believe is in government to create an amendment banning gay marriage is completely hypocritical of the government considering the recent controversy, considering I mean about um, under god in the pledge of allegiance and how people are so opposed to that, but yet they'll let laws be made that enforce religious standards on an entire country. Um, just one, lots of people are anti-gay and anti-gay marriage because they believe that gay people are somehow psychologically damaged, and the gayness has resulted from trauma in their childhood not being close enough to one or the other of the parents, or just a personality defect. And that is also not a good reason, because the American Psychological Association just put out a memo about how untrue that is, and if people listened to um, institutions that actually did research and studies on these subjects instead of listening to their neighbors and their friends and maybe what's popular opinion in their culture in their church then maybe the world would be seen a little bit differently. Okay, so first off, I work in a hospital pharmacy over the summer you know. Even though a drug is illegal, it doesn't mean it has no benefits. (laughs) I was just wondering, I was initially okay with the premise, but I think everyone was still reeling from the 9/11 attacks and this pretext brought us into Iraq, all sorts of pretexts got us into Iraq. I think early on the Bush administration linked the Iraq War to Osama bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, all of which has since been proven false. And that really rubbed me the wrong way and in general, the Iraq War just boils my blood.

(um) It just seems to me that the Bush administration has been openly lying to the American people and has yet to own up to it. Even Colin Powell, I mean after he came back from that big presentation he gave at the UN, now says that he wasn't entirely convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it. And to me, that's just a dereliction of duty, I think it's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the Constitution and has been trying to erode it since at least 9/11, I mean they came into office with the intent to go to war.

(um) That last part... I forgot the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was probably forced out of his office... But it seems that the younger Bush had a blood feud against Saddam Hussein because of his dad's administration and I think in the long run, he was hoping to expand our energy supply too, which is also a very underhanded way to do things.

Well, I do think it's gone on long enough, I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now, though there's a good chance that the country would lapse into civil war and even more people would die as a result. (um) I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving to at this point seems to be a coalition of nations from the surrounding area, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, to come in and try to restore order, but I don't necessarily know that that's a good idea either, because I think in the long run, it will also cause more problems because Iraq's sovereignty will become an issue, a major issue, because I think it's pretty clear that the interim government is dissolving at this point.

Just from the news reports I've heard, it doesn't seem that the Parliament is very effective at all, that um... Okay, the war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war. You're fighting the citizens of the country. So I think that the government, the US government should have planned for all possible outcomes. I think there is still sexism in the United States. It's not just about women; I think it's about the specific field of work you're in. I believe women face more difficulties in certain fields because, even with the theory of equality, many people still have a hard time accepting female leaders. This is because society has had a preconceived notion for a long time. Therefore, women often find themselves qualified for a job, but are rejected, because people think women shouldn't be in high positions. Similarly, men face similar challenges in certain fields, such as fashion and childcare. Usually, the parent is the woman, and the man is expected to be the breadwinner. If a man chooses to stay home and care for the children, society looks down on them: "You should be the one earning money for the family." This puts a lot of pressure on them, as they may have originally wanted to be the primary caregivers, while their wives have better jobs. And in the fashion industry, people will doubt a man's authenticity: "You're not a true fashion enthusiast; your style doesn't fit the industry standards." People question his professionalism, worrying he can't understand women's needs. This also relates to geographical background, because some people may have regional cultural biases against women or men. To change this, we need to gradually promote understanding and acceptance of different groups. We need to avoid forced promotion and instead showcase their strengths and abilities. If we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. So, we need to gradually push for this change, allowing people to slowly accept it. We've made great progress, and change takes time. Actually, besides sexism, geographical background can also lead to other forms of discrimination.

transformed_texts: I think that in some ways the Catholic Church needs to change. They have a lot of views that I think the Catholic Church isn't very accepting of a lot of things, which is why they're losing some of their followers. The Catholic Church has very strong views on things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which I think is fine, but they're a bit old-fashioned in some ways. So I think if they were to adapt to some newer styles of thinking, they wouldn't be worried about losing their followers. I've heard that a lot of people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church a bit because of their views on these issues. Some people are starting to disagree with the Catholic Church on certain subjects, so they feel that the Catholic Church has the wrong views on things. I mean, the Catholic Church is against abortion, so if you're for abortion you might not feel comfortable in a following where that was taught to be completely wrong and something you were against. It's similar with gay marriage, where if that's something you believe in and want to do or feel strongly about, you might not want to be in a following where they disagree with that. I don't see any reason why they can't have female priests or that priests can't be married, but I'm not sure if that would have necessarily prevented these problems. I don't think it would have changed anything, actually. I don't think they would have done anything differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were female priests. The Catholic Church says that priests are married to God and devoted to their whole life, but I don't see why regular people can't have both a job and a family life, so I don't see why priests can't have both.

I personally don't object to same-sex marriage. Well, I think it's not a conscious choice, whether you're born that way or whatever. I don't think gay people should be held accountable for their sexual orientation. So, I think it's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married but not two people of the same sex. It seems like it's not a choice, like they don't have a choice in how they are. I was born straight, and another person is born gay, it doesn't seem like it's a conscious choice that they should be held responsible for. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal issue, I don't know if I want to call it a moral issue. I don't think they should be judged or put on a stage, like they made a wrong decision or choice or whatever. So I don't think the federal government really has any say. It's hard. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it has nothing to do with the security of our country, it has nothing to do with moral concerns or anything like that, it just seems like they're out of place. They don't seem to have the right to intervene in people's lives, and that's just who they are - like they were born that way or at least that's what I think. And I think they shouldn't be punished for that.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because basically there's not a good reason not to. It's just like two different sides of the same coin. Heads will never be tails, but it's like the same thing. There are a lot of civil rights that go along with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing where your primary or your next of kin can be in the room with you if you're sick and can visit. And I think that's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. And a lot of scientific studies have been done because it's a hot topic these days, and homosexual couples have the same kind of rates of success, they have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It's just it's a relationship, it's the same thing. And I think where a lot of people get hung up is homosexuals aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state then that shouldn't be an issue. Because I don't understand where people like Catholics can get hung up on oh well that's against our religion and that's morally wrong for us and we can't approve of that sort of thing. But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union why not allow them a marriage. It's like segregation, separate but unequal. (laughs) I was just wondering, I was initially okay with the premise, but I think everyone was still reeling from the 9/11 attacks and this pretext brought us into Iraq, all sorts of pretexts got us into Iraq. I think early on the Bush administration linked the Iraq War to Osama bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, all of which has since been proven false. And that really rubbed me the wrong way and in general, the Iraq War just boils my blood.

(um) It just seems to me that the Bush administration has been openly lying to the American people and has yet to own up to it. Even Colin Powell, I mean after he came back from that big presentation he gave at the UN, now says that he wasn't entirely convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it. And to me, that's just a dereliction of duty, I think it's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the Constitution and has been trying to erode it since at least 9/11, I mean they came into office with the intent to go to war.

(um) That last part... I forgot the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was probably forced out of his office... But it seems that the younger Bush had a blood feud against Saddam Hussein because of his dad's administration and I think in the long run, he was hoping to expand our energy supply too, which is also a very underhanded way to do things.

Well, I do think it's gone on long enough, I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now, though there's a good chance that the country would lapse into civil war and even more people would die as a result. (um) I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving to at this point seems to be a coalition of nations from the surrounding area, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, to come in and try to restore order, but I don't necessarily know that that's a good idea either, because I think in the long run, it will also cause more problems because Iraq's sovereignty will become an issue, a major issue, because I think it's pretty clear that the interim government is dissolving at this point.

Okay, the war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war. However, the government made it seem like there was a connection and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the 9/11 terrorist attacks and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003. Um, I'm against war, especially a preemptive strike, I was against that. And I think the war in Iraq is kind of a repeat of the Vietnam War in many ways. The government should have learned from past mistakes that they made with the Vietnam War. I mean, a tremendous amount of American soldiers have died and that's horrible. What they were doing was removing the countries government and I really don't think the government was prepared for the aftermath and the void of power and the chaos that was going to occur. You're fighting the citizens of the country. So I think that the government, the US government should have planned for all possible outcomes. I think there is still sexism in the United States. It's not just about women; I think it's about the specific field of work you're in. I believe women face more difficulties in certain fields because, even with the theory of equality, many people still have a hard time accepting female leaders. This is because society has had a preconceived notion for a long time. Therefore, women often find themselves qualified for a job, but are rejected, because people think women shouldn't be in high positions. Similarly, men face similar challenges in certain fields, such as fashion and childcare. Usually, the parent is the woman, and the man is expected to be the breadwinner. If a man chooses to stay home and care for the children, society looks down on them: "You should be the one earning money for the family." This puts a lot of pressure on them, as they may have originally wanted to be the primary caregivers, while their wives have better jobs. And in the fashion industry, people will doubt a man's authenticity: "You're not a true fashion enthusiast; your style doesn't fit the industry standards." People question his professionalism, worrying he can't understand women's needs. This also relates to geographical background, because some people may have regional cultural biases against women or men. To change this, we need to gradually promote understanding and acceptance of different groups. We need to avoid forced promotion and instead showcase their strengths and abilities. If we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. So, we need to gradually push for this change, allowing people to slowly accept it. We've made great progress, and change takes time. Actually, besides sexism, geographical background can also lead to other forms of discrimination.

I think the Catholic Church needs to make some changes in a few ways. They have many people talking about how the Catholic Church is losing some of its followers, and I think it's because the Catholic Church isn't very accepting of a lot of things.

In the case of gay marriage, in the case of abortion, in the case of birth control, things like that. I think the Catholic Church has very strong views on them, which is fine. But their views are a little old-fashioned in some ways. So I think if they were to adapt to a newer style of thinking, they wouldn't be worried about losing their followers.

I've heard there are a lot of people starting to have a little bit of a negative view of the Catholic Church because of the way they see these situations, and people are starting to not agree with them on certain subjects. So they feel that the Catholic Church has the wrong view on things.

Yeah, I mean, the Catholic Church is against abortion, so if you're for abortion, you might not be comfortable in a following where that was taught to be completely wrong, and that you were going against it. And the same goes with gay marriage and things like that - if that's something you believe in and want to do or even just feel strongly about, you might not want to be in a following that doesn't agree with that.

I don't see any reason why they can't have female priests or priests can't be married. But I don't know if that would necessarily have prevented what happened. I mean, I don't know if they would have done that if they were allowed to be married or if there were women priests. But I don't know if that would have necessarily changed it.

Well, I mean, that was something they did, and that was something that didn't really seem to be affected. I mean, if they were married, would they have done it differently? It's hard to really tell.

Yeah, I don't see why priests can't be married. I mean, the Catholic Church really says that the priests are basically married to God, and they're devoted to their complete life. But I don't see why everyone else who has a job in the world has their job, then they also have their family life, and the other people they're devoted to. So I don't see why priests can't have both.

No.

Personally, I don't oppose same-sex marriage. I think, no matter if you're born that way or not, sexual orientation isn't a conscious choice. So I think that people shouldn't be held responsible for their sexual orientation. I think it's wrong to say a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. It doesn't seem like it's a choice they make. Like, I was born straight, and another person is born gay. It doesn't seem like it's a conscious choice they should be responsible for, if you know what I mean.

I don't think the federal government should get involved in this. It's not really a legal issue, and I don't think it's a moral issue either. I don't think gay people should be put on a pedestal and judged for their sexual orientation. So I don't think the federal government really has a say in this. 

It's complicated. (laughs) I don't think the federal government should get involved because it has nothing to do with the security of our country, it's not a moral concern, it's not like anything like that. It just seems like they're out of place. It doesn't seem like they have the right to interfere in people's lives. And that's just who they are - gay people. That's just how they were born, or at least that's what I think, and they shouldn't be punished for that. No, that's it.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because basically there's no good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's so different and there are so many different aspects to it that it could never be considered the same. It's just like two sides of the same coin; heads will never be tails, but it's like the same thing. There are a lot of civil rights that go along with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing where your partner can't be in the room with you if you're sick and can't visit because they're not technically family. I think that's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have been done because it's a hot topic these days, and homosexual couples have the same kind of rates of success, they have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It's just it's a relationship, it's the same thing. I think where a lot of people get hung up is homosexuals aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state, then that shouldn't be an issue. Because I can't understand where people like Catholics can get hung up on, "oh well that's against our religion and that's morally wrong for us and we can't approve of that sort of thing." But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. They are the same in many ways, like the type of relationship roles played by different partners and stuff like that. People worry about adoption issues and community issues, like how a gay couple living in their community will affect the community. And especially about kids of gay couples and how they'll adjust to society and whether or not they'll be influenced by their parents' sexual orientation or not. But well again, it's kind of new and stuff, but it's kind of hard to say I'm not sure about the children aspect about adoption because I think the main drawback to that is how kids get treated by their peers and by other adults in society. Like in New York City, I know they have special schools for kids of gay parents because in public schools in New York City they get beaten up and stuff like that. And parents protest to get the kid removed from their school. And it's just a kid, I mean they'll have the same viewpoints and everything, parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight couples. So they can be community involved or not, like heterosexual couples choose to. I mean it's just about personality choices. I think the federal government should be very involved in this issue, making gay marriage legal in every state, I think the amendment should just be the opposite. But well I think President Bush has very very strong views on his own having to do with his religion. Well his take on gay marriage actually um I think it goes along with his take on abortion and stem cell research which I think most of the reasons I'm not sure about this because honestly I try not to pay attention to politics a lot but most of the reasons I've heard at least like in the news and stuff are moral reasons and morality I don't want to say it's negotiable but it definitely differs from person to person and to embrace the morality of a certain group in America while totally ignoring the culture and morality concepts of all the rest is unethical to just go along with what some religious groups believe without taking into account to go along with what religious groups believe is in government to create an amendment banning gay marriage is completely hypocritical of the government considering the recent controversy considering I mean about under God in the pledge of allegiance and how people are so opposed to that but yet they'll let laws be made that enforce religious standards on an entire country. Um just one lots of people are anti-gay and anti-gay marriage because they believe that gay people are somehow psychologically damaged and the gayness has resulted from trauma in their childhood not being close enough to one or the other of the parents or just a personality defect. And that is also not a good reason because the American Psychological Association just put out a memo about how untrue that is and if people listened to institutions that actually did research and studies on these subjects instead of listening to their neighbors and their friends and maybe what's popular opinion in their culture in their church then maybe the world would be seen a little bit differently. I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer. Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it has no benefits. If it's available to the public, I'd say no, absolutely not. But for medical purposes, I'd say yes. Because just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. It's not beneficial, you know what I mean. 

You know, there are many illegal drugs that pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percoet. They're controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. Denying the benefits of these just because there's a taboo around marijuana doesn't make sense to me. We should accept its benefits.

I don't think it's comparable to alcohol, because if you abuse marijuana, it can still have negative effects, just like alcohol. But it's a tough one. I say, let's integrate it, let it become legal gradually, not all at once, because then it would be abused. But if you just remove the taboo around marijuana first, people might use it responsibly.

People have a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug. But it's not that bad for you, not like heroin or cocaine. If we get rid of the image of marijuana as a horrible thing, people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

I think the church has already adapted to the 21st century. I think the church is not as strict as it used to be. I know that even though I've grown up, when I was a kid, I always went to church every Sunday. I would wear cute little dresses, and matching shoes, and a matching purse. That was just a part of going to church. I went to a private school, and I saw my friends at church on the weekends. We would just go to church. But as I've gotten older, they've set up a teenager mass, and they've shortened the mass to 30 minutes. People dress more casually. Especially in the summer, people would come in their beach clothes straight from the beach. You'd see families running late. So I think it has become more casual. Even at morning mass, I used to always dress up. People are now wearing jeans and khakis. Well, khakis are nice too. But it's just a lot more casual compared to that. As for other things, that's the biggest thing that I've noticed. That's the church I know. I don't know the politics within the church. But yeah, that's it. [Okay, regarding all the accusations against Catholic priests dealing with pedophilia, do you think that these could have been prevented if the church changed, for example, allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry?] I don't think these things could've been avoided. So I think even if you got them married, it's just the person; it's not because they're allowed to get married or not allowed to get married. I think when they become a priest, it's their choice to become a priest. I think there are religions that allow them to get married, like Seventh Heaven. I don't know what kind of [man] he is, but he's a reverend or a minister or something. [Mm hmm] But they're allowed to get married. So I know it's a little different. But if they really wanted to practice their faith and get married at the same time, they should maybe consider a different faith. [Okay, can you elaborate on your answer a little bit more?] Um, I was going to say... about the changes. [That it really wouldn't make a difference, I guess.] Oh, about pedophilia. [Mm hmm] I think... like, the whole thing about sexuality being related to genetics. I think it's based on genetics. I don't think people can just become pedophiles. I think they're born that way. I don't think it has anything to do with how they're raised. It might have something to do in some cases, but I think it's their genetics. And you can't hide that through marriage. You can try, but it usually comes out. So I don't think the church could've done anything to prevent this from happening. If they knew about it and were trying to cover it up, that's shameful. But I don't think in all cases they knew. [Okay, do you have any other thoughts concerning the Catholic Church?] No

Um, I initially was okay with the premise but I think that everyone was still very much reeling from the September 11th attacks and I think that we kind of went in to Iraq as a pretext there were pretexts that led us into Iraq. I think that early on the Bush administration connected the Iraq war with Osama Bin Laden and to the September 11th attacks and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction all of which has since proven false. And that’s very much rubbed me against the grain and in general the Iraq war kind of boils my blood. Um, I think that the Bush administration is very openly lied to the American people and has yet to own up to that fact, even Colin Powell, I mean coming back from that big presentation he gave at the UN now says that he really wasn’t convinced by the evidence at the time even when he was presenting it. And, to me that’s just malfeasance in office, I think that’s an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think that the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since, well since September 11th at least, I mean. I think that they, um, they came into office with the intent to go to war. Um, that last part, I forget the name of the, um, Secretary of the Treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was probably forced out of his office, um, but it seems to be that the younger Bush kind of had came in with a blood vengeance kind of feeling against Saddam Hussein because of his dad’s administration and I think that in the long term he was hoping to expand our energy supply too, which is also very underhanded way to do things. Well, I do think it’s gone on long enough, I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now though cause there’s a good chance that the country would lapse into civil war and even more people would die as a result, um, I think that the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving to at this point seems to be kind of like a coalition of nations from the surrounding area like Syria and Saudi Arabia to come in and try to restore order, but I don’t necessarily know that that’s a good idea either because I think in the long term that will also cause more problems because, um, Iraq’s sovereignty will come to be an issue, a major issue there because I think it’s pretty clear that the interim government is dissolving at this point. Just from the news reports I’ve heard it doesn’t seem that the Parliament is very effective at all, that um, oh I can’t remember his name but the Prime Minister really has any kind of control over the political process or what’s happening and even Muqtada al-Sadr the guy we were fighting, I guess it was less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament and I mean we’re still dealing with la fractious radical elements who are vying for control of the government and I think that the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that. Um, (laughs) none that I can articulate in polite company

I think this is completely not right, the government should not interfere with religious views. I think this should not be something that the government can declare as legal. Let's see, I've always supported gay marriage. I've always been. This is a very personal thing, and now more and more research shows that orientation is biological rather than social, so we shouldn't deprive them of their rights due to something they can't control. 

In my opinion, this is inhumane. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage. I think politics and government shouldn't have any role in this; this is not a national issue, it's a personal issue, it's a household issue. In my neighborhood at home, I know there are two or three openly gay couples who are not married because they're not allowed to. But they function the same way any other family would. They walk the dogs down the street just like anyone else. I think Bush is trying to redefine marriage and interpret the words the way he wants. I think it's ridiculous.

Actually, research shows that there's a chemical thing in your brain that might make you homosexual. It's not because of environment or social influence, so that's a biological issue, not a social one.

However, aside from the obvious, I think another issue is that marriage is something that if a guy and a girl want to do it, they can secretly go to Las Vegas and do it, but if two guys want to do it, it'll be on the front page of the New York Times. I think it should be a personal and private affair, rather than a public or national issue.

Uh, when you put something on the internet, it's like a public forum. It's completely public. You can't do anything about it. I mean, as an RA, I've actually dealt with this before. Uh, when you put something out there, it affects how people think of you. If you're talking about blowing things up or shootings, someone's going to say something. You can't put that out there; you can't put that out to the whole world. The internet is seen by everyone. If your friend on Myspace gets that bulletin, obviously, it wasn't the school that got the bulletin. Someone went to the school, and they have to take action. They can't just let it be because then God forbid something happens, they could have prevented it. But again, you don't know what to take seriously because some people just fool around like that. I mean, it could be like the situation we had at school. It could be an experiment that went terribly wrong for a sociology class. Sorry, I couldn't remember the word for a minute. And it could also be something very serious. I think. What happened here was that someone overheard someone saying something in school, and then they reported it. When we finally found out who the person was, his friend looked through his Facebook and became very worried because there were some certain things on there that he might have meant as a joke. But in light of the situation, those things became very serious. When you put something out into the public forum of the internet, there's really no invasion of privacy that happens. If you don't want it out there, don't put it there. If you don't want someone to find it, if you don't want someone to think something of you, you can't control what they think. You can't control what people take seriously or not. I mean, I don't think school officials should be friending their students on Myspace and Facebook and monitoring their Facebooks and Myspaces and all those things and Xangas and Live Journals. But if it is brought to the attention of the school officials, there's really no invasion of privacy because it's brought by someone who you gave access to. And if there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I mean, like I said, I don't think they should be monitoring phone conversations and texts and IMs. If it's brought to their attention, then it's a different story. Uh, yeah. Like, a teacher shouldn't make a Facebook or a Myspace account under a different name and friend their students because that's the same thing. I wouldn't friend my residents because frankly, I don't want to know if they're going out and drinking and then posting their pictures on Facebook. Then that pops up, and I have to see that and I have to do something about it. It's not my job, so I don't want that kind of connection. Um, not really.

I feel the war has been dragged out too long. 
I think the original purpose was good. 
To restore democracy in another country. 
However, I think we've long since lost sight of that purpose. 
Now, we are acting only to prove that we're a superpower in the world. 
I think the original motivation was influenced by George Bush's father's previous conflicts with Saddam Hussein. 
So, if the original purpose was to give democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would be a fair motivation, but not if there were personal interests involved. 
I think we conveyed our purpose in the first few months, just by starting the war. That was a statement in itself. 
However, the war has lasted for over a year or even several years, and I think it's just too long. 

If our purpose was to give democracy to a country under a tyrant's rule, I think that's a just reason for the war. 
But I don't think our reason has been misunderstood and misconceived over time. 
It seems like we're still at war just for the sake of war, not to end the war. 
We don't want to end the war without a decisive victory. 

I think the war has lasted too long, and it should end. 
Their government officials will have to take care of themselves anyway.

I think that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. It's not just women who face this problem, I think it's related to the specific field you're working in. I think women face more difficulties because even though there's supposed to be equality, many people still have a hard time accepting a woman as a leader. This is mainly due to societal habits. In the workplace, women may see a job that suits them and has all the qualifications, but the board will refuse to promote them to that position because historically, women are not seen as leaders in the business world. The same goes for men, especially in the fashion industry or taking care of the family at home. It's really uncommon for men to stay at home and take care of the children, and people look down on them because society thinks that men should be working to make a living, not staying at home. It's hard for men who want to stay at home and take care of their children, especially if their wives have better jobs and they're doing well. In the fashion industry, people don't take men seriously because they think it's not masculine to be interested in fashion. I'm not sure if this makes sense, but I think it's because people think men and fashion don't go well together. So if a man is in the fashion industry, people will think, "How do I know if you really know about fashion if you're a man?" Like, they don't really know what our case is like, like other guys. Depending on the field of work you're in, I think there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. It's hard to change because society has a set mindset, and we've made a lot of progress, but it's slow. I think if we continue at the pace we are now, and women are becoming CEOs and getting more accepted in the business world, it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. And similarly, as men become stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because people realize, "Oh, maybe the woman does have the better job, or she wants to be the one working." And for fashion, people will be like, "Oh, wait, maybe they're listening to their female friends or their wives, and they do know where I'm coming from." So I guess you kinda have to promote it by showcasing the good qualities of the people who are stereotyped against without being too pushy, because if you force it, people will resist. And I think we're at a good balance where it's starting to be enforced like that. So I don't really know if there's anything we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast, people will resist and we've made a lot of progress, and change takes time. Yes. And I guess people are also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or where you're from, like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't the best, but you're extremely intelligent and you work your way up to a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like, "How do I know you're really what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?" So yeah, sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don't know, I guess that's another example. Not really.

I think they didn't completely legalize it, they decriminalized it. You know, it went from a criminal offense to like a traffic ticket. You know, something you just get cited for rather than having to get booked and arrested and brought in and all of that, and then have to come to court once, maybe twice, maybe three times, and have to pay the judge and the state attorney's office has to take on the charge and basically press the charges, and that's a lot of money. So, when you're looking at municipalities that are financially in trouble, they're not willing to make that kind of concession even if it would free up a lot of money for them. Like a lot of communities are rightfully against marijuana, they don't want to do that, but in a place like Denver where people tend to be more open-minded, I think it's totally fine, and I'm sure that their municipality has a lot more money now that they can spend on public education, that they can spend on social programs for the elderly and that they can spend on food programs for the homeless people. 

I think it's important because marijuana isn't something you just want out and about everywhere all over the streets and stuff, there's a whole financial element to it as well. Other reasons why it shouldn't necessarily be legalized are well, if it were totally legalized, I guess you could make it like cigarettes where it could be sold in gas stations and people would be smoking it everywhere, then I mean, I guess a lot of people would be like smoking and driving, and it's still kind of taboo in our society in a lot of places and a lot of contexts to smoke marijuana. To have it out in the open like that would just be awkward to a lot of people. 

And I think in general, alcohol has more debilitating effects on your motor skills, but I think in general, marijuana has a more adverse effect on people's lifestyle as opposed to just their decision making motor skills, I mean, they both have their adverse effects, and I mean, they both are bad in their own way, but I feel like when it comes to substances in general, like no two people really react the same way, I mean, and then people, some people have personalities that are just more normal and they just kind of go all out with everything they have, and then some people know how to exercise moderation and then some people don't, so it's hard to generalize about the substance when people react differently. But I definitely think that they both have their own adverse effects.

I was actually raised in a Christian home, so the topic of homosexuality is somewhat of a gray area for me. Because I have many gay friends, I don't agree with that lifestyle entirely. I think it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue. However, I think it should be up to each state to decide rather than the president deciding for the entire country. Many states are Democratic, and many are Republican, so Democratic states will naturally support gay marriage. If you live in a Democratic state, you will know how that state feels about the issue. I don't think you have the right to disagree with the decision if a state decides to legalize gay marriage, because you chose to live there, so you should respect the state's decision. I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I think it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I have already answered that. I don't think Bush should decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to individual states to decide whether to legalize it; I don't agree with his ban. I just think that since Bush doesn't live in every single state, he shouldn't be able to decide how each state should run itself. I think some things should be left to each individual state. He'll be out of office in about two years, and if a Democratic president decides to lift the ban on gay marriage, it will just go back and forth. It should be up to each individual state because they will have to live with the decision, not the president. No, I don't.

In the case of gay marriage, in the case of abortion, in the case of birth control, things like that. I think the Catholic Church has very strong views on them, which is fine. I think that gay marriage should be legalized because basically there's no good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's so different and there are so many different aspects to it that it could never be considered the same. It's just like two sides of the same coin; heads will never be tails, but it's like the same thing. There are a lot of civil rights that go along with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing where your partner can't be in the room with you if you're sick and can't visit because they're not technically family. I think that's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have been done because it's a hot topic these days, and homosexual couples have the same kind of rates of success, they have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It's just it's a relationship, it's the same thing. I think where a lot of people get hung up is homosexuals aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state, then that shouldn't be an issue. Because I can't understand where people like Catholics can get hung up on, "oh well that's against our religion and that's morally wrong for us and we can't approve of that sort of thing." But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. They are the same in many ways, like the type of relationship roles played by different partners and stuff like that. In the workplace, women may see a job that suits them and has all the qualifications, but the board will refuse to promote them to that position because historically, women are not seen as leaders in the business world. The same goes for men, especially in the fashion industry or taking care of the family at home. It's really uncommon for men to stay at home and take care of the children, and people look down on them because society thinks that men should be working to make a living, not staying at home. It's hard for men who want to stay at home and take care of their children, especially if their wives have better jobs and they're doing well. In the fashion industry, people don't take men seriously because they think it's not masculine to be interested in fashion. I'm not sure if this makes sense, but I think it's because people think men and fashion don't go well together. So if a man is in the fashion industry, people will think, "How do I know if you really know about fashion if you're a man?" Like, they don't really know what our case is like, like other guys. Depending on the field of work you're in, I think there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. It's hard to change because society has a set mindset, and we've made a lot of progress, but it's slow. I think if we continue at the pace we are now, and women are becoming CEOs and getting more accepted in the business world, it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. And similarly, as men become stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because people realize, "Oh, maybe the woman does have the better job, or she wants to be the one working." And for fashion, people will be like, "Oh, wait, maybe they're listening to their female friends or their wives, and they do know where I'm coming from." So I guess you kinda have to promote it by showcasing the good qualities of the people who are stereotyped against without being too pushy, because if you force it, people will resist. And I think we're at a good balance where it's starting to be enforced like that. So I don't really know if there's anything we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast, people will resist and we've made a lot of progress, and change takes time. Yes. And I guess people are also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or where you're from, like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't the best, but you're extremely intelligent and you work your way up to a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like, "How do I know you're really what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right?" So yeah, sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don't know, I guess that's another example. Not really.

I think they didn't completely legalize it, they decriminalized it. You know, it went from a criminal offense to like a traffic ticket. You know, something you just get cited for rather than having to get booked and arrested and brought in and all of that, and then have to come to court once, maybe twice, maybe three times, and have to pay the judge and the state attorney's office has to take on the charge and basically press the charges, and that's a lot of money. So, when you're looking at municipalities that are financially in trouble, they're not willing to make that kind of concession even if it would free up a lot of money for them. Like a lot of communities are rightfully against marijuana, they don't want to do that, but in a place like Denver where people tend to be more open-minded, I think it's totally fine, and I'm sure that their municipality has a lot more money now that they can spend on public education, that they can spend on social programs for the elderly and that they can spend on food programs for the homeless people. 

I think it's important because marijuana isn't something you just want out and about everywhere all over the streets and stuff, there's a whole financial element to it as well. Other reasons why it shouldn't necessarily be legalized are well, if it were totally legalized, I guess you could make it like cigarettes where it could be sold in gas stations and people would be smoking it everywhere, then I mean, I guess a lot of people would be like smoking and driving, and it's still kind of taboo in our society in a lot of places and a lot of contexts to smoke marijuana. To have it out in the open like that would just be awkward to a lot of people. 

And I think in general, alcohol has more debilitating effects on your motor skills, but I think in general, marijuana has a more adverse effect on people's lifestyle as opposed to just their decision making motor skills, I mean, they both have their adverse effects, and I mean, they both are bad in their own way, but I feel like when it comes to substances in general, like no two people really react the same way, I mean, and then people, some people have personalities that are just more normal and they just kind of go all out with everything they have, and then some people know how to exercise moderation and then some people don't, so it's hard to generalize about the substance when people react differently. But I definitely think that they both have their own adverse effects.

I would say yes because

I was actually raised in a Christian home, so the topic of homosexuality is somewhat of a gray area for me. Because I have many gay friends, I don't agree with that lifestyle entirely. I think it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue. However, I think it should be up to each state to decide rather than the president deciding for the entire country. Many states are Democratic, and many are Republican, so Democratic states will naturally support gay marriage. If you live in a Democratic state, you will know how that state feels about the issue. I don't think you have the right to disagree with the decision if a state decides to legalize gay marriage, because you chose to live there, so you should respect the state's decision. I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I think it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I have already answered that. I don't think Bush should decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to individual states to decide whether to legalize it; I don't agree with his ban. I just think that since Bush doesn't live in every single state, he shouldn't be able to decide how each state should run itself. I think some things should be left to each individual state. He'll be out of office in about two years, and if a Democratic president decides to lift the ban on gay marriage, it will just go back and forth. It should be up to each individual state because they will have to live with the decision, not the president. No, I don't.

I think the Catholic Church needs to make some changes in a few ways. They have many people talking about how the Catholic Church is losing some of its followers, and I think it's because the Catholic Church isn't very accepting of a lot of things.

In the case of gay marriage, in the case of abortion, in the case of birth control, things like that. I think the Catholic Church has very strong views on them, which is fine. But their views are a little old-fashioned in some ways. So I think if they were to adapt to a newer style of thinking, they wouldn't be worried about losing their followers.

I've heard there are a lot of people starting to have a little bit of a negative view of the Catholic Church because of the way they see these situations, and people are starting to not agree with them on certain subjects. So they feel that the Catholic Church has the wrong view on things.

Yeah, I mean, the Catholic Church is against abortion, so if you're for abortion, you might not be comfortable in a following where that was taught to be completely wrong, and that you were going against it. And the same goes with gay marriage and things like that - if that's something you believe in and want to do or even just feel strongly about, you might not want to be in a following that doesn't agree with that.

It doesn't seem like it's a conscious choice they should be responsible for, if you know what I mean.

I don't think the federal government should get involved in this. It's not really a legal issue, and I don't think it's a moral issue either. That's just how they were born, or at least that's what I think, and they shouldn't be punished for that. No, that's it.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because basically there's no good reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the heterosexual family, but it's so different and there are so many different aspects to it that it could never be considered the same. It's just like two sides of the same coin; heads will never be tails, but it's like the same thing. There are a lot of civil rights that go along with it, like property taxes and the whole healthcare thing where your partner can't be in the room with you if you're sick and can't visit because they're not technically family. I think that's kind of silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have been done because it's a hot topic these days, and homosexual couples have the same kind of rates of success, they have the same factors in the relationship that contribute to satisfaction as heterosexual couples do. It's just it's a relationship, it's the same thing. I think where a lot of people get hung up is homosexuals aren't asking for the right to get married in a church, they're asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. And if there's no involvement with church and state, then that shouldn't be an issue. Because I can't understand where people like Catholics can get hung up on, "oh well that's against our religion and that's morally wrong for us and we can't approve of that sort of thing." But in a legal sense, if you're allowing someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation, separate but unequal. They are the same in many ways, like the type of relationship roles played by different partners and stuff like that. So they can be community involved or not, like heterosexual couples choose to. I mean it's just about personality choices. I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer. Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it has no benefits. If it's available to the public, I'd say no, absolutely not. But for medical purposes, I'd say yes. Because just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. It's not beneficial, you know what I mean. 

You know, there are many illegal drugs that pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percoet. They're controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. Denying the benefits of these just because there's a taboo around marijuana doesn't make sense to me. We should accept its benefits.

I don't think it's comparable to alcohol, because if you abuse marijuana, it can still have negative effects, just like alcohol. But it's a tough one. I say, let's integrate it, let it become legal gradually, not all at once, because then it would be abused. But if you just remove the taboo around marijuana first, people might use it responsibly.

People have a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug. But it's not that bad for you, not like heroin or cocaine. If we get rid of the image of marijuana as a horrible thing, people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

I think the church has already adapted to the 21st century. I think the church is not as strict as it used to be. I know that even though I've grown up, when I was a kid, I always went to church every Sunday. I would wear cute little dresses, and matching shoes, and a matching purse. That was just a part of going to church. I went to a private school, and I saw my friends at church on the weekends. We would just go to church. But as I've gotten older, they've set up a teenager mass, and they've shortened the mass to 30 minutes. People dress more casually. Especially in the summer, people would come in their beach clothes straight from the beach. You'd see families running late. So I think it has become more casual. Even at morning mass, I used to always dress up. People are now wearing jeans and khakis. Well, khakis are nice too. But it's just a lot more casual compared to that. As for other things, that's the biggest thing that I've noticed. That's the church I know. I don't know the politics within the church. But yeah, that's it. I think that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. It's not just women who face this problem, I think it's related to the specific field you're working in. I think women face more difficulties because even though there's supposed to be equality, many people still have a hard time accepting a woman as a leader. This is mainly due to societal habits. In the workplace, women may see a job that suits them and has all the qualifications, but the board will refuse to promote them to that position because historically, women are not seen as leaders in the business world. The same goes for men, especially in the fashion industry or taking care of the family at home. It's really uncommon for men to stay at home and take care of the children, and people look down on them because society thinks that men should be working to make a living, not staying at home. I think it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue. However, I think it should be up to each state to decide rather than the president deciding for the entire country. Many states are Democratic, and many are Republican, so Democratic states will naturally support gay marriage. If you live in a Democratic state, you will know how that state feels about the issue. I don't think you have the right to disagree with the decision if a state decides to legalize gay marriage, because you chose to live there, so you should respect the state's decision. I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I think it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I have already answered that. I don't think Bush should decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to individual states to decide whether to legalize it; I don't agree with his ban. He'll be out of office in about two years, and if a Democratic president decides to lift the ban on gay marriage, it will just go back and forth.
